title: Deferred Prosecution and Court Supervision Statistics

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Deferred Prosecution and Court Supervision Statistics
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Monthly statistics and final disposition on following charges:
1. Retail theft 
2. PCS/Cannabis 
3. Theft 
4. Burglary 
5. Possession of a Stolen Motor Vehicle 
6. Forgery 
7. ID Theft/Unlawful use of a credit card/fictitious ID 
8. Criminal Damange to Government property 
9. Counterfeit Trademark/Deceptive Practice
10. Unlawful use of Recording Device
11. Disorderly Conduct

and whether deferred prosecution or a diversion program or court supervision was offered for the previously mentioned charges from 2011 to August 2025.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

FOIA Chicago

title: Communications Regarding SCREEN/KOSA Acts and Foreign NGO Influence

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Communications Regarding SCREEN/KOSA Acts and Foreign NGO Influence
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

from January 1, 2022, to present concerning:

1.The Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) and/or the SCREEN Act, including internal drafts, reviews, or recommendations.

2.Communications, emails, meeting logs, or policy submissions involving:
- a) National Center on Sexual Exploitation (NCOSE)
- b) Collective Shout
- c) CEASE (Centre to End All Sexual Exploitation)
- d) Carnegie UK Trust
- e) Yoti (digital ID software provider)

3.Discussions regarding age verification systems, child internet safety standards, or external digital identity technologies.

This request is submitted with reference to the July 25, 2025 Interim Staff Report of the U.S. House Judiciary Committee titled:
“The Foreign Censorship Threat: How the European Union’s Digital Services Act Compels Global Censorship and Infringes on American Free Speech.”

This report documents concerns that foreign laws are being used to impose domestic censorship goals through indirect means. This FOIA request seeks to determine whether similar tactics were employed by the aforementioned NGOs or agencies.

I request a waiver of fees as this is a matter of significant public interest. I am submitting this on behalf of Alathea LLC.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Demosthenes Alathea

title: Public Records Request – Sandra Hemme Investigation, Interrogation, and Related Files

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: Public Records Request – Sandra Hemme Investigation, Interrogation, and Related Files
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Custodian,

 I hereby request access to all public records related to the investigation, prosecution, and reversal of the conviction of Sandra Hemme in the 1980 murder of Patricia Jeschke—including previously undisclosed or newly surfaced documents.

Specifically, I seek:

1. All audio and video recordings of interrogations of Sandra Hemme from November–December 1980—including interviews conducted at hospitals or crime scenes.


2. Transcripts or handwritten notes of each interrogation session.


3. Detective and investigative reports, including observations on Hemme’s mental and physical condition during questioning and references to the now-deceased officer Michael Holman.


4. Internal memos, emails, or reports regarding the handling, storage, or withholding of evidence


5. Chain-of-custody logs for key physical evidence and any documents submitted during the 2024 evidentiary hearing.


6. Policy or correspondence related to exculpatory evidence—especially involving visits to the crime scene, psychological vulnerability, and coercive interrogation tactics.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P061105-080625
communications.communication:
Dear Brown Pearl: 
Our office received your open records request pursuant to Missouri's Sunshine Law, Chapter 610, RSMo. Your request has been assigned number P061105-080625. The Patrol is committed to adhering to the Sunshine Law and to ensuring that the public obtains access to open records that are not otherwise closed by law. The Sunshine Law requires each public agency to adhere to certain standards. This letter is designed to ensure that you understand our process for fulfilling your records request. Three Business Day Notice Requirement: 
The requested records are not immediately available for dissemination or inspection. The Patrol is required to notify you that additional research time will be required to fulfill the request. This correspondence satisfies the Sunshine Law's notice requirement within the required three business day period. Section 610.023.3, RSMo. 
 Additional Research Time is Required: 
The Patrol receives thousands of open records requests each month. Our Patrol Records Division personnel are dedicated to meeting the intent of Missouri's Sunshine Law and strive to respond to each request in a timely manner. The Patrol operates in all 114 Missouri counties and the independent city of St. Louis. Accordingly, many records maintained by the agency are not centrally located within, or immediately accessible to, the Patrol's Custodian of Records in Jefferson City. Our staff must research your request and ensure that we have captured all responsive records  ̶  regardless of their location within the agency. The research process is time-consuming, but we will make every effort to expedite your request. Estimated Time for Completion: 
The majority of our requests are fulfilled within thirty business days. Some requests require additional research time due to their scope or complexity. Our team will conduct an initial review of your request. If we estimate that the request will be fulfilled within thirty business days, we will not send an updated time estimate. However, if we estimate that the request will take longer than thirty business days, we will provide an updated time estimate that provides a detailed justification for the additional research time. Billing: 
As it relates to billing, Missouri law allows the Patrol to charge fees for copies and research time. Specifically, "[r]esearch time required for fulfilling records requests may be charged at the actual cost of research time." Section 610.026, RSMo. The Missouri Supreme Court recently determined that "staff time is the time required to provide access to public records maintained on computer facilities, recording tapes or disks, videotapes or films, pictures, maps, slides, graphics, illustrations or similar audio or visual items". Gross v. Parson, 624 S.W.3d 877, 884-89 (Mo. 2021) (internal quotations omitted). 
The Patrol will never bill you for redaction time or any research time conducted by our legal staff. You will only be charged for copies and staff research time as permitted by Missouri law. Please let us know if you have questions related to the billing estimate. 
Our team will forward a bill estimate to your attention once we have calculated the permissible costs and fees. The Patrol will not provide the responsive records until receipt of payment. Section 610.026.2, RSMo. 
We appreciate your patience as we review, research, and fulfill your open records request. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will receive an email when your request has been completed. If you wish to withdraw or clarify your request, or if you have questions, please call our office at (573) 526-6146, or (573) 526-6167. 
 
Sincerely, 
Gerard G. Callahan 
Custodian of Records 
 
Login Link: https://mshp.govqa.us/WEBAPP/_rs/Login.aspx

title: FOIL Request – Arrest of Jodi Haddad (June 2024, Victory Chrysler, Rome, NY)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: FOIL Request – Arrest of Jodi Haddad (June 2024, Victory Chrysler, Rome, NY)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law (Public Officers Law §84 et seq.), I request unredacted digital copies of all video footage related to the arrest of Jodi Haddad, age 48, of Stockbridge, NY, who was arrested in June 2024 for allegedly stealing over $50,000 from Victory Chrysler in Rome, NY.

According to public reports, Haddad was charged with grand larceny and falsifying business records following a two-month investigation by the Oneida County Sheriff's Office. She was arraigned and released pending a future court date in Rome City Court.

Please include all body-worn camera, dashcam, interior patrol car, and interview room footage related to her arrest, transport, and processing.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Daniele Mazzei

title: Public Records Request – Interrogation Footage and Confession Records of Henry McCollum and Leon Brown (1983 Case, Robeson County)

communications.subject: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request – Interrogation Footage and Confession Records of Henry McCollum and Leon Brown (1983 Case, Robeson County)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Officer,

 I am requesting access to public records pertaining to the interrogation, confession, arrest, and conviction of Henry McCollum and Leon Brown, in relation to the 1983 murder of Sabrina Buie in Red Springs, Robeson County.

Specifically, I request:

1. Any audio or video recordings of the interrogations of Henry McCollum and/or Leon Brown conducted in or around September 1983.


2. Transcripts or written statements/confessions extracted during these interrogations.


3. Detective notes or internal reports summarizing the interrogation process or referencing the confessions.


4. Chain of custody or custody logs indicating where interrogation-related materials have been stored or maintained.


5. Any additional materials that were entered as evidence in court or reviewed during post-conviction proceedings, especially in relation to:

Motions to suppress

Allegations of coercion

Cognitive disability evaluations of the defendants

The confessions obtained during these interrogations were later called into question and invalidated after DNA evidence exonerated both men in 2014, identifying another individual as the true perpetrator.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

title: FOIA Request – Interrogation Footage & Related Records: Jessie Misskelley Jr. – West Memphis Three Case

communications.subject: Arkansas Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Request – Interrogation Footage & Related Records: Jessie Misskelley Jr. – West Memphis Three Case
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arkansas Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Custodian of Records,

I respectfully request access to and copies of public records related to the interrogation of Jessie Misskelley Jr., which took place on or about June 3, 1993, in connection with the investigation of the West Memphis Three case (State of Arkansas v. Jessie Misskelley Jr., CR-93-450).

I am specifically requesting:

1. Any and all audio and/or video recordings of the police interrogation of Jessie Misskelley Jr., including full unedited sessions.


2. Transcripts, typed or handwritten, of the interrogation proceedings.


3. Officer reports or notes, including any documentation detailing the duration, location, or methods used in the interrogation.


4. Any records indicating video editing, omissions, or redactions, including chain of custody reports.


5. If available, records referenced in court proceedings, including exhibits submitted in CR-93-450, that pertain to the interrogation footage or its content.



This interrogation was central to the prosecution’s case and has been referenced in numerous court filings, appeals, and legal reviews, including:

Misskelley’s Motion to Suppress Confession (1993),

Arkansas Supreme Court opinion in Misskelley v. State, 915 S.W.2d 702 (Ark. 1996),

and subsequent reviews by legal scholars and innocence projects.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sonny Albarado, a citizen of Arkansas, in coordination with Brown Pearl.

title: Decertification List

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Decertification List
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

DCJS's Master Decertification List,  including  but not limited to all pending, final, prior and reinstated police decertification data. 

Data dictionary and documentation 
I also request all documentation that describes the layout of the database’s tables and fields, and that provides the definitions of any field names, codes, and abbreviations used in the database. This information may be gathered together in a single document like a data dictionary, entity layout, or user's guide. If that is the case, I request access to and copy of said document. Should the records above represent certain values as numeric codes or abbreviations that are not self-explanatory, I additionally request all records necessary to interpret those codes and abbreviations.

Data format 
I request these records in their native digital formats and not in formats that degrade the accessibility of the records, such as tabular data converted to PDF or Word files. If converting the native digital format to another high-fidelity format, such as CSV or Excel, please take care not to introduce formatting inconsistencies or errors, which can occur in the conversion process (for example, encoding errors or the inclusion of internal unescaped quotation marks in CSV files).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Dillon Bergin.

received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

**

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBIâ€™s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBIâ€™s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the â€˜Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request toolâ€™ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

title: Epstein List II

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

In a February 2025 appearance on Fox News, Attorney General Pam Bondi was asked the following by a Fox News journalist: “The DOJ may be releasing the list of Jeffrey Epstein’s clients. Will that really happen?” Bondi responded: “It is sitting on my desk right now to review. That has been a directive by President Trump. I am reviewing that.”  You can see the full interview here: https://www.foxnews.com/politics/bondi-says-epstein-client-list-sitting-my-desk-right-now-reviewing-jfk-mlk-files

I seek all of the Epstein-related records that Bondi was referring to during this interview appearance, including the document or documents she was referring to when she stated "It is sitting on my desk right now to review." This request also seeks the "list of Jeffrey Epstein's clients" that Bondi was asked about by the Fox News reporter and confirmed having in her possession during the interview appearance.

I do not seek a copy of the publicly available list of Epstein's associates that was unsealed by a judge in 2024 in a civil lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell, and which is described in this CBS News article: https://www.cbsnews.com/news/jeffrey-epstein-list-associates-unsealed-judge-rules/

I am a reporter for The Nation magazine and other outlets. I seek a fee waiver, but if that waiver is denied I am willing to pay up to $25 for these records.

I seek expedited processing for this request. The information I seek could shed light on a matter of urgent and compelling public interest -- namely, the potential involvement of federal government personnel in the alleged sex trafficking operation organized by the late Jeffrey Epstein. This information is at the center of public discourse at this moment, and the Epstein case is a matter that involves the White House, Congress and numerous judicial bodies. It is imperative that the public obtain information on this matter in a timely matter, particularly given the corrosive effects the Epstein case has had on trust in government. For the reasons above, I ask that my request be given expedited processing because there is an urgency to inform the public about actual or alleged federal government activity, and I am a person primarily engaged in disseminating information. I intend to use the requested records to inform the public about actual government activity. I certify the foregoing to be true and correct to the best of my knowledge and belief.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jimmy Tobias

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Public Information Officer,

Under the Texas Public Information Act, I am requesting access to all available records related to the conviction and exoneration of Ernest Willis, who was wrongfully convicted of arson and sentenced to death in 1987, then exonerated in 2004.

Interrogation footage/transcripts, reports from Pecos County law enforcement

Arson investigation reports, expert testimony, and appeals

Any Texas Rangers or DPS involvement in re-investigating the case

Sincerely,

Brown Pearl

communications.communication:

All information, analyses, summaries, assessments, transcripts, news clippings, email threads, text messages, or similar records included in National Security Correspondence related to an article titled "The Agency" written by a journalist named Adrian Chen and published in The New York Times Magazine on June 2nd of 2015.

title: Arthur Companies Rinsate Spill

communications.subject: North Dakota Open Records Law Request: Arthur Companies Rinsate Spill
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Dakota Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

All investigative reports, memos, case files, letters or other records in the possession of the North Dakota Department of Agriculture concerning the Arthur Companies' 2017 spill of rinsate, which contaminated the farm field of Donald Garnas in or around Page, North Dakota. This request includes any records in the possession of pesticide enforcer Tyler Kralicek. For more information on the case in question, please see this news story: https://www.feedandgrain.com/safety/news/15398184/north-dakota-ag-finds-rinsate-violation-at-grain-elevator

This request seeks records produced since June 1, 2017 and the date this request is processed. I am a reporter for Public Domain and other national news outlets and seek a fee waiver.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Jimmy Tobias

communications.subject: RE: North Dakota Open Records Law Request: Arthur Companies Rinsate Spill - NDDA response to email open public records request
communications.communication:
Mr Tobias,

Please permit me to introduce myself.   I am general counsel to the North Department of Agriculture (NDDA).  Your below email open public records request has been forwarded to me.

I reviewed your below open public records request requesting NDDA records.  I am responding back to you on behalf of NDDA.

In your attached open public records request, you requested:

All investigative reports, memos, case files, letters or other records in the possession of the North Dakota Department of Agriculture concerning the Arthur Companies' 2017 spill of rinsate, which contaminated the farm field of Donald Garnas in or around Page, North Dakota.  This request includes any records in the possession of pesticide enforcer Tyler Kralicek.

These pesticide records you request, if they exist, are confidential under N.D.C.C. § 4.1-33-21(5)(a).  These requested records, if they exist, would pertain to pesticide application, sales, purchases, and repackaging.

N.D.C.C. § 4.1-33-21(5)(a) says:


  *   "At any reasonable time, the commissioner may access records pertaining to the pesticide application, sales, purchases, and repackaging by any person.  The commissioner may copy or make copies of the records for the purpose of this chapter.  These records are confidential.  ...  Any record the commissioner uses as an exhibit in an enforcement action is no longer a confidential record."

Id. (emphasis added).

In accordance with N.D.C.C. § 4.1-33-21(5)(a) immediately above, NDDA records related to violation investigations (or any other records that pertain to pesticide application, sales, purchases, and repackaging) are confidential unless:  (1) the records have been used as an exhibit in an enforcement action; or, (2) as confidential records, the records are released under a court order in accordance with N.D.C.C. § 44-04-18.11.

In relation to the above-mentioned matter:


  *   None of these requested records have been used as an exhibit in an enforcement action.


  *   No party to any applicable litigation has requested a court to order the confidential records disclosed.  If such confidential records are directed to be disclosed pursuant to a court order, in conjunction with such a court order, NDDA commonly seeks a protective order for the disclosed confidential records (to only disclose the records to the parties of the case, and to prevent further disclosure).  In this regard, in cases involving private civil litigation in which the NDDA is not a party, a reasonable accommodation might be worked in which NDDA objects to the third-party subpoena served by a party to the litigation, and a judge may then order the release of the otherwise confidential documents to all parties to that ligation under appropriate protective handling instructions.

Finally, for your further reference, in accordance with N.D.C.C. § 4.1-33-21.5(b):


  *   "If an individual alleges exposure to pesticides and if the individual's medical provider requests that the commissioner reveal the name of the pesticide, the commissioner may reveal the name of the pesticide to the individual making the request, together with the registration number assigned by the United States environmental protection agency.  The commissioner may require a request under this section be made in writing."

Accordingly, in view of N.D.C.C. § 4.1-33-21.5(b) immediately above:  if (1) human pesticide exposure is at issue; (2) you allege an individual's alleged exposure to pesticides; and, (3) that individual's medical provider requests the name of the pesticide in writing, the agriculture commissioner will then review the written request and make a determination as to whether the name of the pesticide and its registration number may be released.

I am unaware of any pending or active litigation in relation to this matter.  If litigation has been commenced regarding this matter, please provide me a copy of the filed complaint

Any charges associated with this email response to the below email open records request, dated August 5, 2025, are waived.

Please direct any additional questions or concerns in relation to these above matters to me at (701) 328-1496 or bialkej@nd.gov<mailto:%20bialkej@nd.gov>.

Sincerely,

Dutch Bialke

J.P. "Dutch" Bialke
General Counsel/Senior Policy Advisor
Special Assistant Attorney General
ND Department of Agriculture
600 E. Boulevard Ave., Dept. 602 | Bismarck, ND  58505-0020
P: 701.328.1496 | F:  701.328.4567
bialkej@nd.gov
www.nd.gov/ndda<http://www.nd.gov/ndda>

communications.subject: RE: North Dakota Open Records Law Request: Arthur Companies Rinsate Spill
communications.communication:
Hello Mr. Bialke,

Thank you for the note. I appreciate your quick response. Based on the reporting from the Bismarck Tribune, the Agricultural Department brought an enforcement action against Arthur Companies for the rinsate spill in question. Is it your contention that none of the records related to this enforcement action can can be disclosed to the public? Would none of the records qualify as exhibits related to an enforcement action?  I am also curious about the specific language of the disclosure exemption. My understanding of the situation is that the contamination in question did not concern "application, sales, purchases, and repackaging" of pesticides, but rather the "disposal" of pesticides, which would indicate to me that these records do not fall under the provision you cited. Please clarify if possible and thank you.

We are very eager to make these records public. If the Department will not release these records, what are next steps in terms of appealing the Department's decision?

Thanks again.

Jimmy Tobias 
2487630088
jtoby87@gmail.com

communications.subject: RE: North Dakota Open Records Law Request: Arthur Companies Rinsate Spill
communications.communication:
Mr Tobias,
Thank you for our congenial phone conversation this morning.  As discussed,, the Department has no records responsive to your request.

Please be advised that, according to the State of North Dakota, Department of Agriculture, Pesticide Division Records Retention policy series 800307 (Enforcement Actions, Investigations, and Court Proceedings), records retention is five (5) years after the case is closed).  Presuming that any enforcement action in this matter took place and was concluded in either 2017 or 2018, any records, if they existed, would have been disposed of in either 2022 or 2023 respectively.


Here's the file '602-008 Pesticide Enforcement.pdf:


https://acrobat.adobe.com/id/urn:aaid:sc:VA6C2:8a20ab12-d146-4b09-9ff5-cdf2f1667151

Please let me know if you have any further questions or if I can be of any further assistance.

All the best,

Dutch

General Counsel/Senior Policy Advisor
Special Assistant Attorney General
ND Department of Agriculture
600 E. Boulevard Ave., Dept. 602 | Bismarck, ND  58505-0020

communications.communication:
Jimmy

Thank you for your below email open public records request, dated yesterday August 5, 2025, and corresponding follow up emails.

I once again spoke with the Pesticide Division of the Department of Agriculture.

I was again told that no electronic or hard copy records exist regarding the below matter:

“the Arthur Companies' 2017 spill of rinsate, which contaminated the farm field of Donald Garnas in or around Page, North Dakota.”

Once again, please be advised that, according to the State of North Dakota, Department of Agriculture, Pesticide Division Records Retention policy series 800307 (Enforcement Actions, Investigations, and Court Proceedings), records retention is five (5) years after the case is closed).  Presuming that any enforcement action in this matter took place and was concluded in either 2017 or 2018, any records, if any records existed, the records would have been disposed of in either 2022 or 2023 respectively.

In short, the Department has no records responsive to your open public records request, dated August 5, 2025.

Notwithstanding the above, if any records existed, as explained in previous emails, the records likely would be confidential under N.D.C.C. § 4.1-33-21(5)(a).

This email, along with all below emails from the Department in the below email string, serve as an official response to your open public records request, dated August 5, 2025.

Any charges associated with this official email response to the below email open records request, dated August 5, 2025, are waived.

Please continue to direct any additional questions or concerns in relation to these above matters to me at (701) 328-1496 or bialkej@nd.gov.
All the best,

Dutch

communications.subject: Kentucky Open Records Act Request: Aggregated Statewide Property Parcel Data
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Kentucky Open Records Act (KRS 61.870 et seq.), I hereby request the following records:

I request electronic copies of all aggregated statewide property parcel data maintained by the Department of Revenue, including but not limited to: parcel numbers, account numbers, location addresses, subdivisions, descriptions, classes, tax districts, deed info, acres, owner information, valuations (with history, exemptions, and taxable assessments), improvement details, land details (e.g., plat books, lot sizes, zoning, flood planes), sales history, recent comparables, photos, historical property cards, and any associated GIS data or shapefiles. Please provide in a machine-readable format such as CSV, Excel, or database export.

If certain data is not available at the state level, please specify exactly what is missing and direct me to the appropriate county sources. This request is for a commercial project. Please provide a fee estimate before processing.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment or secure download link if available.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ethan Moore

All City records are open for personal inspection and copying by any person except for portions of records which contain exempt or confidential information which may not be disclosed unless otherwise permitted by law.  While the City strives to provide access to public records by remote electronic means, it is necessary that the records are reviewed for possible exempt or confidential information prior to disclosure.  Should the records contain exempt or confidential information that is required to be redacted, the City will need to bill for the time expended on making the necessary redactions.  Should any extraordinary time be required, the City charges administrative fees as authorized by Florida Statutes.  An estimate of charges will be provided for prepayment prior to work being processed.

08-06-25 Ben  Heckscher N/A MuckRock News, DEPT MR190635, 263 Huntington Ave Boston, MA  02115 Dear Mr. Heckscher: This letter acknowledges the receipt of your FOIA request dated 08-05-25 requesting To Whom It May Concern:Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:The minutes for any meeting of the Amtrak Board of Directors that occurred in the month of January 2025.The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.Sincerely,Ben HeckscherUpload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Famtrak-479%252Famtrak-board-of-directors-meeting-minutes-jan-2025-3rd-request-190635%252F%253Femail%253DFOIAPublicLiaison%252540amtrak.com&url_auth_token=AAATVczgYa5hDtGppW4msQn1q3M%3A1ujUI2%3AGVSA1QZmV22z04UGbsgVs1uzjyZAbcHp_iLS7NF7-LQ. This request has been issued tracking number 25-FOI-00507.  Please reference this number in all correspondence and communications with this office. 
If you have any questions regarding the processing of your request, please feel free to contact me at Rebecca.Conner@amtrak.com or at 202-906-3215.  For further assistance and to discuss any aspect of your request you may also contact our FOIA Public Liaison at FoiaPublicLiaison@amtrak.com.  Additionally, you may contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS), National Archives and Records Administration, Room 2510, 8601 Adelphi Road, College Park, MD  20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov, telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448; or fax 202-741-5769. Thank you, FOIA Officer

title: Patel appointment

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Patel appointment
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Introductory announcement, prepared remarks, agenda items, and other materials related to the appointment of Ricky J. Patel as special agent in charge of the New York Area of Responsibility.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Felipe De La Hoz
